In OrbiT around SpaceT

Our Vision

Centuries ago, humanity set sail past the Seven Seas only to other worlds of endless wonder. With every nation on earth setting their sights on the stars, the people should not be left behind.

HisTory of SpaceT

Setting up our base...

In the year 2020, a deadly virus held a strong grip on our planet. Travelling was never going to be the same until a vaccine was created, which nobody could tell when it would be finished. And while most went to look for sanctuaries within their own countries, we focused on laying the foundation for our first Star Port.

Taking to the skies

After 3 years of hard work, our Commander in Chief Dirk Van Goethem led the first voyage to the moon. With a crew of 5 cadets and a lucky few passengers, they arrived on the barren landscape of our natural satellite, at a stone throw from our Base Lunar - X Ã† A-12. Two weeks later, they successfully engaged thrusters homebound, where they arrived in little under 2 days time.

Setting course

Not long after our first mission, we opened up to the public for enlisting. In our first 5 years, we completed approximately 70 passenger flights to Mars, Venus and the Moon, with a success rate of 99%.

The only issues we encountered were faulty reignition systems, ending up in 2 crews being stranded at our holiday resorts for a few weeks longer. Yet all passengers were sufficiently refunded, and were able to spend an extended time in space. Soon after, our science teams started working on expanding our holiday folder, with special attention for Neptune and Jupiter.

In perfect orbit

After 20 years of non-stop functionality, we can now safely say we are in a perfect orbital state around our goals and vision. We have seen countless happy and amazed faces among our customers, and can pride ourselves in our customer service and support.

We would never have dreamed to get this far, and be able to think even bigger, and look beyond our own solar system. We are now working on a shuttle system that can take us to the closest inhabitable planet within reach: Proxima b.
